headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: So you finished 2016 with $1.9 billion remaining on the buyback and about $2.2 billion more cash on the balance sheet than when you exited 2015. So it seems reasonable to assume you'd expect to execute the vast majority, if not all, of the remaining autho
componenttext: So you finished 2016 with $1.9 billion remaining on the buyback and about $2.2 billion more cash on the balance sheet than when you exited 2015. So it seems reasonable to assume you'd expect to execute the vast majority, if not all, of the remaining authorization in 2017. But at the same time, there are some restructuring costs to consider, and we've recently seen you prioritize M&A in the form of Nat Sherman. So -- and I appreciate you're not going to want to give guidance on this, but just I'd love a little bit more color on how to think about cash priorities in the coming years just given all those moving parts.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. Billy?
componenttext: Sure. Billy?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks for the question, Steve. You're right we had $1.9 billion leftover at the end of the last year. From a standpoint of cash needs or the way we think about capital allocation, nothing has changed. And so when we announced that program, we said w
componenttext: Yes. Thanks for the question, Steve. You're right we had $1.9 billion leftover at the end of the last year. From a standpoint of cash needs or the way we think about capital allocation, nothing has changed. And so when we announced that program, we said we would complete it by the middle of 2018. And you can see with the progress we've made, we're on track to do that. And so really, nothing has changed either from a cash needs or cash priorities or from the capital allocation process. But thank you for the question.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Great. And just one more on iQOS, and thanks for the prior updates that you've been providing in this call. But you mentioned some of the learnings you're drawing from other markets as you look around the world and plan for launch in the U.S. I was wonder
componenttext: Great. And just one more on iQOS, and thanks for the prior updates that you've been providing in this call. But you mentioned some of the learnings you're drawing from other markets as you look around the world and plan for launch in the U.S. I was wondering if there's anything unique to your strengths in the U.S. that you might also be uniquely positioned to deploy? And I'm thinking specifically of your mobile app and your digital activation capabilities? And how that may play into any rollout of iQOS? And how that may differ from other rollouts we've seen around the world?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a good question. We do -- as you know, we discussed previously, we have a strong digital marketing team. And I'm really proud of the work they're doing on the core business. And you're right to think that there are a lots of applications that
componenttext: Yes, that's a good question. We do -- as you know, we discussed previously, we have a strong digital marketing team. And I'm really proud of the work they're doing on the core business. And you're right to think that there are a lots of applications that if you're trying to communicate and educate consumers about what products are that digital is the way to go. It has to be done carefully and responsibly, of course, and I don't think anybody would be surprised to learn that we're considering that and others. We have, I think, a significant competitive advantage in our sales force. It's large. They're very talented. They're very well led and so naturally, we would be thinking, as we go to market, about how we can use that to help iQOS be successful. I think we have excellent relationships with our trade partners. That's another area that's going to require a lot of thinking about how we take iQOS to market and working with our trade partners. So those are all areas of inspection. And you're thinking about it the right way, which is what is it that we have that we can use to the best effect to make iQOS a big success.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2017

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Growe of Stifel.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: I had a question for you, if I could. First, in relation to pricing, there was a little larger price increase taken back in November, and I know that could be beneficial for profitability, but I suspect you want to reinvest some of that. At the same time,
componenttext: I had a question for you, if I could. First, in relation to pricing, there was a little larger price increase taken back in November, and I know that could be beneficial for profitability, but I suspect you want to reinvest some of that. At the same time, you have a couple cost-savings plans that you're also reinvesting back in the business. So I wanted to understand with that incremental pricing, do we think about that as being another lever, if you will, for you to reinvest back in the business? And are there any areas you're trying to accelerate your investment beyond what you already talked about?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2017

componenttext: Yes. Thanks for the question, Chris. This is Billy. From a standpoint of our productivity, as we previously talked about, some of that productivity will fall to the bottom line, some from a reinvestment. I wouldn't read too much into any specific individual price increase. We think about pricing over the long term. And so we make those decisions for that in that regards. And it's really to balance for our long-term financial goals of that 7 to 9 to return.

componenttext: Yes. Chris, this is Billy. We don't project any significant changes in inventory. You know they always fluctuate over a shorter time period, that SET does go into place April 1. componenttext: I'd like to tell you more, but honestly, the close was just so recently, we're working through all of that now. componenttext: Yes, I think from a standpoint of -- we don't guide down to that level. But to explain how we build it into our guidance, you're right, we built a range of scenarios for all of the factors that we incorporate into guidance. So we ran a range of scenarios on those very similar to the way we would have with SAB. The only difference is we have a one quarter accounting lag. And so the fourth quarter of 2016 will be recognized in '17 and then that lag will carry forward. We'll have a full 4 quarters in 2017. One quarter will be from the fourth quarter of '16 and the first 3 quarters of '17. And that's the way we incorporate into guidance.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Altria Group 2017 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is scheduled to last about 1 hour, including remarks by Altria's management and the question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] I will now like
componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the Altria Group 2017 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is scheduled to last about 1 hour, including remarks by Altria's management and the question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] 
I will now like to turn the call over to Mr. Bill Marshall, Vice President, Investor Relations for Altria Client Services. Please go ahead.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Crystal. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. We're here this morning with Marty Barrington, Altria's CEO; and Billy Gifford, our CFO, to discuss Altria's 2017 first quarter business results.Earlier today, we issued a press release pro
componenttext:
Thank you, Crystal. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. We're here this morning with Marty Barrington, Altria's CEO; and Billy Gifford, our CFO, to discuss Altria's 2017 first quarter business results.
Earlier today, we issued a press release providing these results, which is available on our website at altria.com and through the Altria investor app. 
During our call today, unless otherwise stated, we're comparing results to the same period in 2016. Our remarks contain forward-looking and cautionary statements and projections of future results. Please review the Forward-looking and Cautionary Statement section at the end of today's earnings release for various factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from projections. Future dividend payments and share repurchases remain subject to the discretion of Altria's board. The timing of share repurchases depends on marketplace conditions and other factors. 
Altria reports its financial results in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles. Today's call will contain various operating results on both a reported and adjusted basis. Adjusted results exclude special items that affect the comparability of reported results. Descriptions of these non-GAAP financial measures and reconciliations are included in today's earnings release.
Now I'll turn the call over to Marty.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us. Altria is off to a solid start in 2017 despite some short-term headwinds. We grew first quarter adjusted diluted earnings per share by 1.4%, against the difficult comparison in the year ago q
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us. Altria is off to a solid start in 2017 despite some short-term headwinds. We grew first quarter adjusted diluted earnings per share by 1.4%, against the difficult comparison in the year ago quarter when we grew adjusted diluted EPS more than 14%. 
The smokeable products segment continue to generate strong results, which offset lower equity earnings from our beer investment and the effect of the voluntary product recall in the smokeless product segment. 
Our business fundamentals remain strong, and we believe we're well positioned for the rest of the year. 
Earlier this morning, we reaffirmed our 2017 full year adjusted diluted EPS growth guidance of 7.5% to 9.5%, and we continued to expect adjusted diluted EPS growth to be weighted to the second half. 
Here are some color on the businesses. The smokeable products segment grew its adjusted operating company's income by more than 8%. PM USA estimates that cigarette industry volume declines were in line with the historical rate as the industry lapped the improving consumer conditions and benefits from lower gasoline prices. Against this backdrop, the industry remains competitive and PM USA saw several competitive product expansions and promotional changes. In this environment, PM USA remained focused on maximizing income while maintaining momentum on Marlboro across its measures of brand strength, which include equity, demographics, retail share and profitability. 
PM USA implemented leased price increases in March and continued to compete effectively at retail. PM USA was steady in its strategy and execution resulting in strong smokeable segment price realization. 
And the machine made large cigar category Middleton's focus on the more profitable tipped cigar segment continued to generate good results, and the business is performing very well. The cigar category strength and trade inventory movements drove Middleton's reported shipment volume up over 12% in the quarter. 
Turning to the smokeless products segment. It was a disappointing quarter resulting from the product recall caused by a product tampering incident. USSTC did the right thing by moving quickly to address the issue with consumers, the trade and other stakeholders, but the recalls affect shows in the numbers. Smokeless segment adjusted OCI declined 7.8% and USSTC estimates that the recall had an approximately 1 retail share point impact. 
The recall is concluded, and USSTC has now largely completed replenishing wholesale and retail inventories. We expect that USSTC will recover the share loss over time. 
Turning to innovative tobacco products. Altria continues to develop a portfolio of products to meet evolving adult tobacco consumer preferences. In April, Nu Mark announced the expansion of MarkTen to approximately 10,000 more stores and the availability of 3 more flavors for its adult papers: winter mint, summer fusion and smooth cream. 
In heated tobacco, Altria continues to partner with Philip Morris International in seeking regulatory authorization to commercialize the ICOS system in the U.S., both the Modified-Risk Tobacco Product and premarket tobacco product applications for ICOS now have been submitted with the FDA. PM USA's team continues to build its U.S. commercialization plan for ICOS. 
So in summary, we believe that Altria remains well positioned for the rest of the year, and thus, we are reaffirming our full year guidance. 
Now here's Billy for a more detail on our performance.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty, and good morning, everyone. Let me start with the smokeable product segment. Adjusted OCI margins expanded by 2.9 percentage points in the first quarter to 51% due primarily to higher net pricing and lower resolution expenses. Smokeable rep
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty, and good morning, everyone. Let me start with the smokeable product segment. Adjusted OCI margins expanded by 2.9 percentage points in the first quarter to 51% due primarily to higher net pricing and lower resolution expenses. Smokeable reported cigarette shipment volume declined 2.7% in the quarter. After adjusting for trade inventory movements and other factors, PM USA estimates that its cigarette volume declined approximately 3% in line with PM USA's estimate for the industry decline rate. 
In addition, California cigarette SCT, which went into effect on April 1, will also affect shipment volumes in the short term. PM USA's first quarter retail share was 51%, down 1/10 of a share point. Marlboro's retail share declined by two-tenths of a share point to 43.6%. In smokeless, adjusted OCI margins decreased by 3.6 percentage points to 61.9% driven principally by the recall impact partially offset by higher pricing. 
The recall drove USSTC shipment volume down 5% in the quarter. USSTC estimates that smokeless industry volume grew at approximately 2% over the past 6 months. 
It was a tough quarter for wine. Ste. Michelle's adjusted OCI of $21 million was 25% lower than last year and its margins contracted 4.6 percentage points to 15.4% due to lower volume and higher cost. Ste. Michelle's lower volume was driven by whole service reducing year-end inventory and the timing of the Easter holiday, which occurred in the first quarter of last year. 
Let's now turn to our beer investment. As a reminder, ABI's fourth quarter 2016 results are included in our first quarter results due to the reporting lag. 
In the quarter, Altria's reported equity earnings from our investment in ABI were $23 million. These results included net pretax charges of $73 million for ABI special items. 
As ABI noted in its fourth quarter earnings release, its underlying results were negatively impacted by a challenging environment in Brazil and mark-to-market losses related to ABI's hedging of its share-based compensation payment programs. 
We, of course, continue to focus on our shareholders. In the quarter, we returned a large amount of cash to them, paying nearly $1.2 [ billion ] in dividends and repurchasing over $550 million in shares. 
As of March 31, Altria had approximately $1.4 billion remaining in the current $3 billion share repurchase program. We continue to expect completing this program by the end of the second quarter of 2018. 
As Marty mentioned, we continue to expect that our 2017 adjusted diluted earnings growth will be higher in the second half. This is primarily -- this is due primary to the [ potential ] effect of USSTC's recall this quarter and the benefit of reporting 4 full quarters of equity income from our ABI investment. 
Lastly, a quick word on IRI's retail market share reporting. As a result of IRI's most recent database restatement, cigarette and smokeless retail market shares have been restated. Share information for each quarter of 2016 is available in our press release. You'll remember that IRR uses a sample of retail stores and certain wholesale shipments to project market share and depict share trends. Historical trends of restated numbers are generally consistent with those under IRI's previously reported numbers. That wraps up our results. 
Marty and I are now happy to take your questions. While the calls are being compiled, I'll direct your attention to altria.com. Along with today's earnings release and our non-GAAP reconciliations, we posted for your reference our usual list of quarterly metrics, including pricing, inventory and other housekeeping items. 
Operator, we're ready for the questions.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Bonnie Herzog with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Bonnie Herzog with Wells Fargo.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: I actually have a question on Marlboro, and it looks like you've been losing slight share behind Marlboro over the past several quarters based on the adjusted data. So I guess I'd like to better understand your current strategy with the brand and if some
componenttext: I actually have a question on Marlboro, and it looks like you've been losing slight share behind Marlboro over the past several quarters based on the adjusted data. So I guess I'd like to better understand your current strategy with the brand and if some of the new SKUs haven't been as effective as you had hoped and what your innovation pipeline looks like for the remainder of the year behind the brand?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Bonnie, thanks for the question. Listen, I think the best explanation of Marlboro was the one we gave at CAGNY just a little while ago. As you know, Marlboro remains the strongest brand by far in the cigarette category. It's the iconic brand in the catego
componenttext: Bonnie, thanks for the question. Listen, I think the best explanation of Marlboro was the one we gave at CAGNY just a little while ago. As you know, Marlboro remains the strongest brand by far in the cigarette category. It's the iconic brand in the category. I think it's also useful to remember what our strategy is. Our strategy in smokeable is to maximize income while maintaining momentum on Marlboro over time. And so as we've explained, momentum is viewed by us across various metrics. Let me just mention a few of them. One is brand equity, and brand equity from Marlboro has never been higher, indeed. I think the number we gave was 14 points higher than the next nearest competitor. Demographics are good. As you know, we've stabilized its share among the important 21 to 29 cohort. And actually, Marlboro share is very good across all the rest of the cohorts as well. Its profitability is undeniable. I think the number we put up at CAGNY was $34 billion in retail share -- in retail sales in 2016. And then we come to share. And so which share, we look at it over time. It's down [ 2/10 ] in the quarter to be sure, but that's why we look at it over time because promotions and the like come in and out of the quarter. If you look at it over a longer period, I don't know, say, 2011, we've gained call it a share point and a half to 2 share points. So the strategy hasn't changed at all, hasn't changed at all. It's to be a leading brand in the category and to maximize its profitability.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then I wanted to ask a question on your wine business. You mentioned it was certainly a tough quarter. Your margins were very low, probably the lowest they've actually been for a number of years. So I guess I was hoping you guys
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then I wanted to ask a question on your wine business. You mentioned it was certainly a tough quarter. Your margins were very low, probably the lowest they've actually been for a number of years. So I guess I was hoping you guys could drill down a little further in some of the things that hurt your business during the quarter. You mentioned your volume was very weak due to the wholesalers reducing year-end inventory. So more color on this. And then any sense what your volume was excluding this inventory fluctuation? And then finally, this begs a question, which I've asked you guys about before, but would love to hear any updated thoughts or plans that you might have for this business over the next several years in terms of further investments and if you need to actually increase your investments possibly to turn the business around.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks for the question. Listen, I think you have to put the wine quarter in context. If you look at its income growth over the last 5 years, it's grown double-digit. Call it, I don't know, 12%, give or take. And so you have to place the quarter in
componenttext: Okay, thanks for the question. Listen, I think you have to put the wine quarter in context. If you look at its income growth over the last 5 years, it's grown double-digit. Call it, I don't know, 12%, give or take. And so you have to place the quarter in context. They have a tough quarter, there's no denying it. There was inventory that got burned off from the end of the year and the Easter holiday was pushed back into the second quarter this year. So that has the effect on all the numbers if you called out in terms of the volume and obviously in terms of the margin. The wine company does a terrific job out there. No quarter is perfect, and this is ours, I guess, for the wine business, but they do a great job. I don't see the need for anyone to think that we have to step up in any materially way with investment in the wine company. It was just a tough quarter.

componenttext: I might be a tad more precise in that if you let me. They're sourcing the product to us, as you know. They're licensing it into us for commercialization. Just essentially, the inverse of the relationship we have on e-vapor, which is we source the product for them for e-vapor outside the United States, and we license the trademark in the IP to them. The only distention, of course, is that before the spin-off, there was IP under the Altria tent, which we retained at the spin-off.

componenttext: Just a quick follow-up on cigarette industry volumes, which improved a bit sequentially versus what we saw on the fourth quarter despite the fact that retail consumption and measure channels appeared to slow. We had some headwinds from slower C-store trends, difficult comp. So how did that 3% compared to your expectations? And are there any favorable dynamics at the consumer level, maybe consumer confidence that you point to is having helped support volumes in the short term?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: I guess our view is that it's going back to about where we expected, Matt, is the honest answer. If we look at long-term trends, call it, a 5-year trend for the industry, it's about 3%. As you know, we were flatter there for the peer that we discussed pre
componenttext: I guess our view is that it's going back to about where we expected, Matt, is the honest answer. If we look at long-term trends, call it, a 5-year trend for the industry, it's about 3%. As you know, we were flatter there for the peer that we discussed previously. Last year was a 2.5%, and now for this quarter we are back in about 3% as our estimate. So RV is that the secular is what drives is it has since 1980s, and it looks to us like it's going about that. In the quarter, there may be some movements in and out because we've got some excise tax activity, particularly in California. But I don't think it's material over the course of the year.

componenttext: Yes, that's interest question. componenttext: No. I would just say that I just distinguish probably how the dynamics with respect to our vapor business, which, as you know, is going quite well with you saw a big boost in the number stores that we're in. componenttext: Hey, a couple of questions. Just, Marty, maybe can just comment on that and how that integration is going and if you are seeing more space, more of your fair share of space in that higher-end of the back bar? And then the broader picture question is on ICOS. And I guess as you guys think about your plans to invest ahead of the approval process, what kind of consumer work have you been able to do? I mean, how do you know that the consumer is going to take on this product? Because obviously, since he can't really launch it in the U.S. until you get that approval, I'm just curious on the sites in the research that you're doing with the consumer to get a sense of what the uptake could be?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. So first on that, Sherman, we're working through our plans now. We closed in January, if memory serves. And we're getting that ready to roll, so I don't really have a lot to tell you about Nat Sherman, yet because were just getting started. On the I
componenttext: Sure. So first on that, Sherman, we're working through our plans now. We closed in January, if memory serves. And we're getting that ready to roll, so I don't really have a lot to tell you about Nat Sherman, yet because were just getting started. On the ICOS consumer work, the situation, of course, which is you're right we don't have the product and market, so we can't to do any in market consumer work. But we certainly can do out of market work, which we are working on, and in particular, we are using the learnings from PMI, which I think we've discussed before. So many of us have been in the international markets and our teams are working quite closely. The idea basically to try to extract trading consumer insights and then try to apply into what we know about our market here. And so we're working on on all of that now. And then when we get in the lead market, that's when we're going to learn more once we have that product available for consumers. So we're trying to do as much as we can to get a fast start. But you're right to point out, and we pointed out you get in the consumers, you have you have to be careful.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: I guess, Marty, the follow-up to that is having been in the international business, are there any markets that you believe are analogous to the U.S. market just in terms of consumer behavior, tax structures, demographics?
componenttext: I guess, Marty, the follow-up to that is having been in the international business, are there any markets that you believe are analogous to the U.S. market just in terms of consumer behavior, tax structures, demographics?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think the better way to look at it, Nik, is that there's no perfect market, but that each of the markets, if you're asking the right question, can give you insights into the behavior. So obviously, in terms of traditional cigarette markets, it's customa
componenttext: I think the better way to look at it, Nik, is that there's no perfect market, but that each of the markets, if you're asking the right question, can give you insights into the behavior. So obviously, in terms of traditional cigarette markets, it's customary to compare the United States more to Western Europe. But obviously, there are insights to be generated from seeing the uptake that's taking place in Japan. So rather than get locked in a geography, we're focusing on the insights.

componenttext: That's quite the best way to describe it. Look, it's always competitive, and we're always monitoring, and we're always adjusting. That's basically how it works. We were trying to provide some color in the quarter about seeing some competitive product expansions and some promotional changes, and PM USA's adjusted appropriately as it always does. But of course, if you look at net pricing for the quarter, you can see that PM USA's realization was still [ above ] 4.5%. componenttext: Yes. Obviously, that announcement just came out yesterday, and so we're taking a look at what it might do to the C-store trade. Obviously, gas is a big deal at C-store, and that's where most of our traffic runs through. So I guess we'd have to take a look and see what it is. I know that there are sort of interest on both sides of the question about whether the gas tax should be raised. So we'll have to wait and see, I guess.

componenttext: So as I look back -- as I think about the cost as a whole, you had really strong OCI in smokable against the smokeless segments, yes, you have the recall, but excluding that, profit looks really strong as well. On the other hand, I guess market share in cigarettes has been a little bit disappointing. So the question is, as you look forward, is there any reason to suppose return to, let's say, more normal [indiscernible] with perhaps less realization -- little less OCI, but equally a better market share trend in cigarettes? And that would be the first question.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, let me respond to that. It's balance is the honest answer. The strategy on the smokable business as you know, [indiscernible] try to maximize our income, and we try to do that, and we have done that I think as you point out quite well over time. At
componenttext: Well, let me respond to that. It's balance is the honest answer. The strategy on the smokable business as you know, [indiscernible] try to maximize our income, and we try to do that, and we have done that I think as you point out quite well over time. At the same time, we want to make sure we have momentum on the key brands and we're mindful of that. So gather at honest answer is the balance.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: All right. Okay. And that just turning back to the FDA, can you sort of -- at CAGNY, you the expense of putting in applications for authorization for your cigars and e-products of very source. Can you just give an update those applications are going, whet
componenttext: All right. Okay. And that just turning back to the FDA, can you sort of -- at CAGNY, you the expense of putting in applications for authorization for your cigars and e-products of very source. Can you just give an update those applications are going, whether you have any response from the FDA? And has there been any news there, what news is there?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: I would say that it is to be as we described it at CAGNY, which is there's much more activity in terms of the interaction between the agency and our operating companies about their applications as they work through. And you're right, it's much more offens
componenttext: I would say that it is to be as we described it at CAGNY, which is there's much more activity in terms of the interaction between the agency and our operating companies about their applications as they work through. And you're right, it's much more offensive than the FDA has estimated. And so we're having to be mindful about which products we pick in order to put applications in because they come with an expense. Look, our strategies to engage constructively with the agency and to try to encourage it to make good policy decisions, and that includes on approval of our submissions. We continue to believe that our submissions are well-founded and in good form, but it's a process, and you have to go through that with FDA. As I would say it's been more the same since we last discussed this at CAGNY.

So if it hadn't been a change for us, but I think that describes the strategy and the approaches we have in the cigar category.

Good day, and welcome to the Altria Group 2017 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is scheduled to last about 1 hour, including remarks by Altria's management and the question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] 
I will now like to turn the call over to Mr. Bill Marshall, Vice President, Investor Relations for Altria Client Services. Please go ahead.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Krystal. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. We're here this morning with Marty Barrington, Altria's CEO; and Billy Gifford, Altria's CFO, to discuss Altria's 2017 first quarter business results.Earlier today, we issued a press releas
componenttext:
Thank you, Krystal. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. We're here this morning with Marty Barrington, Altria's CEO; and Billy Gifford, Altria's CFO, to discuss Altria's 2017 first quarter business results.
Earlier today, we issued a press release providing these results, which is available on our website at altria.com and through the Altria investor app. 
During our call today, unless otherwise stated, we're comparing results to the same period in 2016. Our remarks contain forward-looking and cautionary statements and projections of future results. Please review the Forward-looking and Cautionary Statement section at the end of today's earnings release for various factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from projections. Future dividend payments and share repurchases remain subject to the discretion of Altria's board. The timing of share repurchases depends on marketplace conditions and other factors. 
Altria reports its financial results in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles. Today's call will contain various operating results on both a reported and adjusted basis. Adjusted results excludes special items that affect the comparability of reported results. Descriptions of these non-GAAP financial measures and reconciliations are included in today's earnings release.
Now I'll turn the call over to Marty.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us. Altria is off to a solid start in 2017 despite some short-term headwinds. We grew first quarter adjusted diluted earnings per share by 1.4%, against the difficult comparison in the year-ago q
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us. Altria is off to a solid start in 2017 despite some short-term headwinds. We grew first quarter adjusted diluted earnings per share by 1.4%, against the difficult comparison in the year-ago quarter when we grew adjusted diluted EPS more than 14%. 
The smokeable products segment continue to generate strong results, which offset lower equity earnings from our beer investment and the effect of the voluntary product recall in the smokeless product segment. 
Our business fundamentals remain strong, and we believe we're well positioned for the rest of the year. 
Earlier this morning, we reaffirmed our 2017 full year adjusted diluted EPS growth guidance of 7.5% to 9.5%, and we continue to expect adjusted diluted EPS growth to be weighted to the second half. 
Here are some color on the businesses. The smokeable products segment grew its adjusted operating company's income by more than 8%. PM USA estimates that cigarette industry volume declines were in line with the historical rate as the industry lapped the improving consumer conditions and benefits from lower gasoline prices. Against this backdrop, the industry remains competitive and PM USA saw several competitive product expansions and promotional changes. In this environment, PM USA remained focused on maximizing income while maintaining momentum on Marlboro across its measures of brand strength, which include equity, demographics, retail share and profitability. 
PM USA implemented list price increases in March and continued to compete effectively at retail. PM USA was steady in its strategy and execution resulting in strong smokeable segment price realization. 
In the machine-made large cigar category, Middleton's focus on the more profitable tipped cigar segment continued to generate good results, and the business is performing very well. The cigar category strength and trade inventory movements drove Middleton's reported shipment volume up over 12% in the quarter. 
Turning to the smokeless products segment, it was a disappointing quarter resulting from the product recall caused by a product-tampering incident. USSTC did the right thing by moving quickly to address the issue with consumers, the trade and other stakeholders, but the recall's effect shows in the numbers. Smokeless segment adjusted OCI declined 7.8% and USSTC estimates that the recall had an approximately 1 retail share point impact. 
The recall is concluded, and USSTC has now largely completed replenishing wholesale and retail inventories. We expect that USSTC will recover the share loss over time. 
Turning to innovative tobacco products. Altria continues to develop a portfolio of products to meet evolving adult tobacco consumer preferences. In April, Nu Mark announced the expansion of MarkTen to approximately 10,000 more stores and the availability of 3 more flavors for its adult papers: winter mint, summer fusion and smooth cream. 
In heated tobacco, Altria continues to partner with Philip Morris International in seeking regulatory authorization to commercialize the ICOS system in the U.S., both the Modified-Risk Tobacco Product and premarket tobacco product applications for ICOS now have been submitted with the FDA. PM USA's team continues to build its U.S. commercialization plan for ICOS. 
So in summary, we believe that Altria remains well positioned for the rest of the year and thus, we are reaffirming our full year guidance. 
Now here's Billy for more detail on our performance.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty, and good morning, everyone. Let me start with the smokeable product segment. Adjusted OCI margins expanded by 2.9 percentage points in the first quarter to 51%, due primarily to higher net pricing and lower resolution expenses. Smokeable re
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty, and good morning, everyone. Let me start with the smokeable product segment. Adjusted OCI margins expanded by 2.9 percentage points in the first quarter to 51%, due primarily to higher net pricing and lower resolution expenses. Smokeable reported cigarette shipment volume declined 2.7% in the quarter. After adjusting for trade inventory movements and other factors, PM USA estimates that its cigarette volume declined approximately 3% in line with PM USA's estimate for the industry decline rate. 
In addition, California cigarette SCT, which went into effect on April 1, will also affect shipment volumes in the short term. PM USA's first quarter retail share was 51%, down 0.1 of a share point. Marlboro's retail share declined by 0.2 of a share point to 43.6%. In smokeless, adjusted OCI margins decreased by 3.6 percentage points to 61.9%, driven principally by the recall impact, partially offset by higher pricing. 
The recall drove USSTC shipment volume down 5% in the quarter. USSTC estimates that smokeless industry volume grew at approximately 2% over the past 6 months. 
It was a tough quarter for wine. Ste. Michelle's adjusted OCI of $21 million was 25% lower than last year, and its margins contracted 4.6 percentage points to 15.4% due to lower volume and higher cost. Ste. Michelle's lower volume was driven by wholesalers reducing year-end inventory and the timing of the Easter holiday, which occurred in the first quarter of last year. 
Let's now turn to our beer investment. As a reminder, ABI's fourth quarter 2016 results are included in our first quarter results due to the reporting lag. 
In the quarter, Altria's reported equity earnings from our investment in ABI were $23 million. These results included net pretax charges of $73 million for ABI special items. 
As ABI noted in its fourth quarter earnings release, its underlying results were negatively impacted by a challenging environment in Brazil and mark-to-market losses related to ABI's hedging of its share-based compensation payment programs. 
We, of course, continue to focus on our shareholders. In the quarter, we returned a large amount of cash to them, paying nearly $1.2 billion in dividends and repurchasing over $550 million in shares. 
As of March 31, Altria had approximately $1.4 billion remaining in the current $3 billion share repurchase program. We continue to expect completing this program by the end of the second quarter of 2018. 
As Marty mentioned, we continue to expect that our 2017 adjusted diluted earnings growth will be higher in the second half. This is primarily -- this is due primarily to the financial effect of USSTC's recall this quarter and the benefit of reporting 4 full quarters of equity income from our ABI investment. 
Lastly, a quick word on IRI's retail market share reporting. As a result of IRI's most recent database restatement, cigarette and smokeless retail market shares have been restated. Share information for each quarter of 2016 is available in our press release. You'll remember that IRI uses a sample of retail stores and certain wholesale shipments to project market share and depict share trends. Historical trends of restated numbers are generally consistent with those under IRI's previously reported numbers. That wraps up our results. 
Marty and I are now happy to take your questions. While the calls are being compiled, I'll direct your attention to altria.com. Along with today's earnings release and our non-GAAP reconciliations, we posted for your reference a usual list of quarterly metrics, including pricing, inventory and other housekeeping items. 
Operator, we're ready for the questions.

componenttextpreview: I actually have a question on Marlboro, and it looks like you've been losing slight share behind Marlboro over the past several quarters based on the adjusted data. So I guess I'd like to better understand your current strategy with the brand and if some
componenttext: I actually have a question on Marlboro, and it looks like you've been losing slight share behind Marlboro over the past several quarters based on the adjusted data. So I guess I'd like to better understand your current strategy with the brand and if some of the new SKUs haven't been as effective as you had hoped and what your innovation pipeline looks like for the remainder of the year behind the brand?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Bonnie, thanks for the question. Listen, I think the best explanation of Marlboro was the one we gave at CAGNY just a little while ago. As you know, Marlboro remains the strongest brand by far in the cigarette category. It's the iconic brand in the catego
componenttext: Bonnie, thanks for the question. Listen, I think the best explanation of Marlboro was the one we gave at CAGNY just a little while ago. As you know, Marlboro remains the strongest brand by far in the cigarette category. It's the iconic brand in the category. I think it's also useful to remember what our strategy is. Our strategy in smokeable is to maximize income while maintaining momentum on Marlboro over time. And so as we have explained, momentum is viewed by us across various metrics. Let me just mention a few of them: one is brand equity, and brand equity from Marlboro has never been higher, indeed. I think the number we gave was 14 points higher than the next nearest competitor. Demographics are good. As you know, we've stabilized its share among the important 21 to 29 cohort. And actually, Marlboro shares are very good across all the rest of the cohorts as well. Its profitability is undeniable. I think the number we put up at CAGNY was $34 billion in retail share -- in retail sales in 2016. And then we come to share. And so which share, we look at it over time. It's down 0.2 in the quarter to be sure, but that's why we look at it over time because promotions and the like come in and out of the quarter. If you look at it over a longer period, I don't know, say, 2011, we've gained I don't -- call it 1.5 share point to 2 share points. So the strategy hasn't changed at all, hasn't changed at all. It's to be a leading brand in the category and to maximize its profitability.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then I wanted to ask a question on your wine business. You mentioned it was certainly a tough quarter. Your margins were very low, probably the lowest they've actually been for a number of years. So I guess I was hoping you guys
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then I wanted to ask a question on your wine business. You mentioned it was certainly a tough quarter. Your margins were very low, probably the lowest they've actually been for a number of years. So I guess I was hoping you guys could drill down a little further in some of the things that hurt your business during the quarter. You mentioned your volume was very weak due to the wholesalers reducing year-end inventory. So more color on this. And then any sense what your volume was excluding this inventory fluctuation? And then finally, this begs a question, which I've asked you guys about before, but would love to hear any updated thoughts or plans that you might have for this business over the next several years in terms of further investments and if you need to actually increase your investments, possibly to turn the business around.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks for the question. Listen, I think you have to put the wine quarter in context. If you look at its income growth over the last 5 years, it's grown double-digit. Call it, I don't know, 12%, give or take. And so you have to place the quarter in
componenttext: Okay, thanks for the question. Listen, I think you have to put the wine quarter in context. If you look at its income growth over the last 5 years, it's grown double-digit. Call it, I don't know, 12%, give or take. And so you have to place the quarter in context. They had a tough quarter, there's no denying it. There was inventory that got burned off from the end of the year and the Easter holiday was pushed back into the second quarter this year. So that has the effect on all the numbers if you called out in terms of the volume and, obviously, in terms of the margin. The wine company does a terrific job out there. No quarter is perfect and this is ours, I guess, for the wine business, but they do a great job. I don't see the need for anyone to think that we have to step up in any materially way the investment in the wine company. It was just a tough quarter.

componenttextpreview: I might be a tad more precise in that if you let me. They're sourcing the product to us, as you know. They're licensing it into us for commercialization. We just -- essentially, the inverse of the relationship we have on e-vapor, which is we source the pr
componenttext: I might be a tad more precise in that if you let me. They're sourcing the product to us, as you know. They're licensing it into us for commercialization. We just -- essentially, the inverse of the relationship we have on e-vapor, which is we source the product for them for e-vapor outside the United States, and we license the trademark and the IP to them. The only distinction, of course, is that before the spin-off, there was IP under the Altria tent, which we retained at the spin-off.

componenttext: Right, okay, that's clarifying. componenttext: No, I would agree with you that it's hypothetical, though, I guess. And there's nothing, I guess, that could foreclose the different arrangement being struck than the one that we have today. But what I've described is the arrangement we have today with PMI.

componenttext: Just a quick follow-up on cigarette industry volumes, which improved a bit sequentially versus what we saw in the fourth quarter despite the fact that retail consumption in measured channels appeared to slow. We had some headwinds from slower C store trends, difficult comp. So how did that 3% compared to your expectations? And are there any favorable dynamics at the consumer level, maybe consumer confidence that you point to is having helped support volumes in the short term?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: I guess our view is that it's going back to about where we expected, Matt, is the honest answer. If we look at long-term trends, call it, a 5-year trend for the industry, it's about 3%. As you know, we were flattered there for the period that we've discus
componenttext: I guess our view is that it's going back to about where we expected, Matt, is the honest answer. If we look at long-term trends, call it, a 5-year trend for the industry, it's about 3%. As you know, we were flattered there for the period that we've discussed previously. Last year was a 2.5%, and now for this quarter we are back in about 3% as our estimate. So our view is that the sequential decline is what drives this, it has since the 1980s, and it looks to us like it's going about that. In the quarter, there may be some movements in and out because we've got some excise tax activity, particularly in California. But I don't think it's material over the course of the year.

Any sense you can give on timeline and your level of confidence that you could potentially align those discussions with the outcome of the FDA's review of premarket approval?

componenttextpreview: Yes, that's an interesting question. We are talking to state legislatures about the policy issue of which ICOS is not a part of having differential taxing, obviously, on lower risk products, that would make good sense. And tax policy gets changed over tim
componenttext: Yes, that's an interesting question. We are talking to state legislatures about the policy issue of which ICOS is not a part of having differential taxing, obviously, on lower risk products, that would make good sense. And tax policy gets changed over time. So we're working on that, but I don't have anything new to announce on that, but it is one of the elements of our work streams.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could squeeze in one last one, sorry, just with the advent of deeming in the vapor space, just curious any observations on what the implications have been in -- at retail since August? Have there been changes in retail or inventory levels i
componenttext: Okay. And if I could squeeze in one last one, sorry, just with the advent of deeming in the vapor space, just curious any observations on what the implications have been in -- at retail since August? Have there been changes in retail or inventory levels in vapor? Have you seen better flexibility in being able to secure or manage shelf space as a result of those rules going into effect?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: No. I wouldn't say that I distinguish probably how the dynamics with respect to our vapor business, which, as you know, is going quite well with MarkTen XL you saw a big boost in number stores that we're in. We see very good consumer response to the new p
componenttext: No. I wouldn't say that I distinguish probably how the dynamics with respect to our vapor business, which, as you know, is going quite well with MarkTen XL you saw a big boost in number stores that we're in. We see very good consumer response to the new product. I would say the thing to watch probably from an industry dynamic are the vape shops. So I know you are familiar with that phenomenon, but they now have to deal with FDA regulation, where they didn't have to deal with any before. So we have seen some evidence that there's been a reduction in the number of vape shops and that the volume is moving to more traditional channels, which would be a good development for our business, of course.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. Just a -- Marty, maybe you can just comment on Nat Sherman and how that integration is going and if you're seeing more space -- more of your fair share of space in that higher end of the backbar? And then the broader picture questio
componenttext: A couple of questions. Just a -- Marty, maybe you can just comment on Nat Sherman and how that integration is going and if you're seeing more space -- more of your fair share of space in that higher end of the backbar? And then the broader picture question is on ICOS. And I guess as you guys think about your plans to invest ahead of the approval process, what kind of consumer work have you been able to do? I mean, how do you know that the consumer is going to uptake on this product? Because obviously, since you can't really launch it in the U.S. until you get that approval, I'm just curious on the sites and the research that you're doing with the consumer to get a sense of what the uptake could be?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. So first on Nat Sherman, we're working through our plans now. We closed in January, if memory serves. And we're getting that ready to roll, so I don't really have a lot to tell you about Nat Sherman yet because we're just getting started. On the ICO
componenttext: Sure. So first on Nat Sherman, we're working through our plans now. We closed in January, if memory serves. And we're getting that ready to roll, so I don't really have a lot to tell you about Nat Sherman yet because we're just getting started. On the ICOS consumer work, the situation, of course, which is you're right, we don't have the product in market, so we can't to do any in-market consumer work. But we certainly can do out-of-market work, which we are working on and, in particular, we are using the learnings from PMI, which I think we've discussed before. So many of us have been in the international markets and our teams are working quite closely. The idea basically is to try to extract trade and consumer insights and then try to apply into what we know about our market here. And so we're working on all of that now. And then when we get in the lead market, that's when we're going to learn more, once we have that product available for consumers. So we're trying to do as much as we can to get a fast start. But you're right to point out and we've pointed out, until you get it in the consumers' hands, you have to be careful.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I guess, Marty, the follow-up to that is having been in the international business, are there any markets that you believe are analogous to the U.S. market? Just in terms of consumer behavior, tax structures, demographics.
componenttext: Yes, and I guess, Marty, the follow-up to that is having been in the international business, are there any markets that you believe are analogous to the U.S. market? Just in terms of consumer behavior, tax structures, demographics.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think the better way to look at it, Nik, is that there's no perfect market, but that each of the markets, if you're asking the right question, can give you insights into the behavior. So obviously, in terms of traditional cigarette markets, it's customa
componenttext: I think the better way to look at it, Nik, is that there's no perfect market, but that each of the markets, if you're asking the right question, can give you insights into the behavior. So obviously, in terms of traditional cigarette markets, it's customary to compare the United States more to Western Europe. But obviously, there are insights to be generated from seeing the uptake that's taking place in Japan. So rather than to get a locked in on a geography, we're focused in on the insights.

componenttext: Okay, well, let me respond to that. It's always a balance is the honest answer. headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: I would say it continues to be as we described it at CAGNY, which is there's much more activity in terms of the interaction between the agency and our operating companies about their applications as they work through. And you're right, it's much more expe
componenttext: I would say it continues to be as we described it at CAGNY, which is there's much more activity in terms of the interaction between the agency and our operating companies about their applications as they work through. And you're right, it's much more expensive than the FDA has estimated. And so we're having to be mindful about which products we pick in order to put applications in because they come with an expense. Look, our strategy is to engage constructively with the agency and to try to encourage it to make good policy decisions, and that includes on approval of our submissions. We continue to believe that our submissions are well founded and in good form, but it's a process and you have to go through that with FDA. So I would say, it's been more of the same since we last discussed this at CAGNY.

componenttext: Sure, Michael, this is Billy. Thanks for the question. If you recall, when we look at the cigar category, you have it in basically 3 segments: you've got the tipped, where Black and Mild participates and has over about 90% of that segment. You have the untipped, and then you have the [ noncigarelar ] form. We participate in the tipped and we have basically a large market share there. And so that's why we're running for profitability. That's where most of the profitability is in the cigar category. In the untipped segment, there's a basically a price we're going on where people are competing for volume, but at a very low profitability, and we are really not participating in that segment. So it hasn't been a change for us, but I think that describes the strategy and the approaches we have in the cigar category.

Good day, and welcome to the Altria Group 2017 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is scheduled to last about 1 hour, including remarks by Altria's management and the question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] 
I will now like to turn the call over to Mr. Bill Marshall, Vice President, Investor Relations for Altria Client Services. Please go ahead.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Krystal. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. We're here this morning with Marty Barrington, Altria's CEO; and Billy Gifford, Altria's CFO, to discuss Altria's 2017 first quarter business results.Earlier today, we issued a press releas
componenttext:
Thank you, Krystal. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. We're here this morning with Marty Barrington, Altria's CEO; and Billy Gifford, Altria's CFO, to discuss Altria's 2017 first quarter business results.
Earlier today, we issued a press release providing these results, which is available on our website at altria.com and through the Altria investor app. 
During our call today, unless otherwise stated, we're comparing results to the same period in 2016. Our remarks contain forward-looking and cautionary statements and projections of future results. Please review the Forward-looking and Cautionary Statement sections at the end of today's earnings release for various factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from projections. Future dividend payments and share repurchases remain subject to the discretion of Altria's board. The timing of share repurchases depends on marketplace conditions and other factors. 
Altria reports its financial results in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles. Today's call will contain various operating results on both a reported and adjusted basis. Adjusted results excludes special items that affect the comparability of reported results. Descriptions of these non-GAAP financial measures and reconciliations are included in today's earnings release.
Now I'll turn the call over to Marty.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us. Altria is off to a solid start in 2017 despite some short-term headwinds. We grew first quarter adjusted diluted earnings per share by 1.4%, against a difficult comparison in the year-ago qua
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us. Altria is off to a solid start in 2017 despite some short-term headwinds. We grew first quarter adjusted diluted earnings per share by 1.4%, against a difficult comparison in the year-ago quarter when we grew adjusted diluted EPS more than 14%. 
The smokeable products segment continue to generate strong results, which offset lower equity earnings from our beer investment and the effect of the voluntary product recall in the smokeless product segment. 
Our business fundamentals remain strong, and we believe we're well positioned for the rest of the year. 
Earlier this morning, we reaffirmed our 2017 full year adjusted diluted EPS growth guidance of 7.5% to 9.5%, and we continue to expect adjusted diluted EPS growth to be weighted to the second half. 
Here are some color on the businesses. The smokeable products segment grew its adjusted operating company's income by more than 8%. PM USA estimates that cigarette industry volume declines were in line with the historical rate as the industry lapped the improving consumer conditions and benefits from lower gasoline prices. Against this backdrop, the industry remains competitive and PM USA saw several competitive product expansions and promotional changes. In this environment, PM USA remained focused on maximizing income while maintaining momentum on Marlboro across its measures of brand strength, which include equity, demographics, retail share and profitability. 
PM USA implemented list price increases in March and continued to compete effectively at retail. PM USA was steady in its strategy and execution resulting in strong smokeable segment price realization. 
In the machine-made large cigar category, Middleton's focus on the more profitable tipped cigar segment continued to generate good results, and the business is performing very well. The cigar category strength and trade inventory movements drove Middleton's reported shipment volume up over 12% in the quarter. 
Turning to the smokeless products segment, it was a disappointing quarter resulting from the product recall caused by a product-tampering incident. USSTC did the right thing by moving quickly to address the issue with consumers, the trade and other stakeholders, but the recall's effect shows in the numbers. Smokeless segment adjusted OCI declined 7.8% and USSTC estimates that the recall had an approximately 1 retail share point impact. 
The recall is concluded, and USSTC has now largely completed replenishing wholesale and retail inventories. We expect that USSTC will recover the share loss over time. 
Turning to innovative tobacco products. Altria continues to develop a portfolio of products to meet evolving adult tobacco consumer preferences. In April, Nu Mark announced the expansion of MarkTen to approximately 10,000 more stores and the availability of 3 more flavors for its adult papers: winter mint, summer fusion and smooth cream. 
In heated tobacco, Altria continues to partner with Philip Morris International in seeking regulatory authorization to commercialize the ICOS system in the U.S., both the Modified-Risk Tobacco Product and premarket tobacco product applications for ICOS now have been submitted with the FDA. PM USA's team continues to build its U.S. commercialization plan for ICOS. 
So in summary, we believe that Altria remains well positioned for the rest of the year and thus, we are reaffirming our full year guidance. 
Now here's Billy for more detail on our performance.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty, and good morning, everyone. Let me start with the smokeable product segment. Adjusted OCI margins expanded by 2.9 percentage points in the first quarter to 51%, due primarily to higher net pricing and lower resolution expenses. Smokeable re
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty, and good morning, everyone. Let me start with the smokeable product segment. Adjusted OCI margins expanded by 2.9 percentage points in the first quarter to 51%, due primarily to higher net pricing and lower resolution expenses. Smokeable reported cigarette shipment volume declined 2.7% in the quarter. After adjusting for trade inventory movements and other factors, PM USA estimates that its cigarette volume declined approximately 3% in line with PM USA's estimate for the industry decline rate. 
In addition, California cigarette SCT, which went into effect on April 1, will also affect shipment volumes in the short term. PM USA's first quarter retail share was 51%, down 0.1 of a share point. Marlboro's retail share declined by 0.2 of a share point to 43.6%. In smokeless, adjusted OCI margins decreased by 3.6 percentage points to 61.9%, driven principally by the recall impact, partially offset by higher pricing. 
The recall drove USSTC shipment volume down 5% in the quarter. USSTC estimates that smokeless industry volume grew at approximately 2% over the past 6 months. 
It was a tough quarter for wine. Ste. Michelle's adjusted OCI of $21 million was 25% lower than last year, and its margins contracted 4.6 percentage points to 15.4% due to lower volume and higher cost. Ste. Michelle's lower volume was driven by wholesalers reducing year-end inventory and the timing of the Easter holiday, which occurred in the first quarter of last year. 
Let's now turn to our beer investment. As a reminder, ABI's fourth quarter 2016 results are included in our first quarter results due to the reporting lag. 
In the quarter, Altria's reported equity earnings from our investment in ABI were $23 million. These results included net pretax charges of $73 million for ABI special items. 
As ABI noted in its fourth quarter earnings release, its underlying results were negatively impacted by a challenging environment in Brazil and mark-to-market losses related to ABI's hedging of its share-based compensation payment programs. 
We, of course, continue to focus on our shareholders. In the quarter, we returned a large amount of cash to them, paying nearly $1.2 billion in dividends and repurchasing over $550 million in shares. 
As of March 31, Altria had approximately $1.4 billion remaining in the current $3 billion share repurchase program. We continue to expect completing this program by the end of the second quarter of 2018. 
As Marty mentioned, we continue to expect that our 2017 adjusted diluted earnings growth will be higher in the second half. This is primarily -- this is due primarily to the financial effect of USSTC's recall this quarter and the benefit of reporting 4 full quarters of equity income from our ABI investment. 
Lastly, a quick word on IRI's retail market share reporting. As a result of IRI's most recent database restatement, cigarette and smokeless retail market shares have been restated. Share information for each quarter of 2016 is available in our press release. You'll remember that IRI uses a sample of retail stores and certain wholesale shipments to project market share and depict share trends. Historical trends of restated numbers are generally consistent with those under IRI's previously reported numbers. That wraps up our results. 
Marty and I are now happy to take your questions. While the calls are being compiled, I'll direct your attention to altria.com. Along with today's earnings release and our non-GAAP reconciliations, we posted for your reference a usual list of quarterly metrics, including pricing, inventory and other housekeeping items. 
Operator, we're ready for the questions.

componenttextpreview: I actually have a question on Marlboro, and it looks like you've been losing slight share behind Marlboro over the past several quarters based on the adjusted data. So I guess I'd like to better understand your current strategy with the brand and if some
componenttext: I actually have a question on Marlboro, and it looks like you've been losing slight share behind Marlboro over the past several quarters based on the adjusted data. So I guess I'd like to better understand your current strategy with the brand and if some of the new SKUs haven't been as effective as you had hoped and what your innovation pipeline looks like for the remainder of the year behind the brand?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Bonnie, thanks for the question. Listen, I think the best explanation of Marlboro was the one we gave at CAGNY just a little while ago. As you know, Marlboro remains the strongest brand by far in the cigarette category. It's the iconic brand in the catego
componenttext: Bonnie, thanks for the question. Listen, I think the best explanation of Marlboro was the one we gave at CAGNY just a little while ago. As you know, Marlboro remains the strongest brand by far in the cigarette category. It's the iconic brand in the category. I think it's also useful to remember what our strategy is. And our strategy in smokeable is to maximize income while maintaining momentum on Marlboro over time. And so as we have explained, momentum is viewed by us across various metrics. Let me just mention a few of them: one is brand equity, and brand equity from Marlboro has never been higher, indeed. I think the number we gave was 14 points higher than the next nearest competitor. Demographics are good. As you know, we've stabilized its share among the important 21 to 29 cohort. And actually, Marlboro shares are very good across all the rest of the cohorts as well. Its profitability is undeniable. I think the number we put up at CAGNY was $34 billion in retail share -- in retail sales in 2016. And then we come to share. And so which share, we look at it over time. It's down 0.2 in the quarter to be sure, but that's why we look at it over time because promotions and the like come in and out of the quarter. If you look at it over a longer period, I don't know, say, 2011, we've gained I don't -- call it 1.5 share point to 2 share points. So the strategy hasn't changed at all, hasn't changed at all. It's to be the leading brand in the category and to maximize its profitability.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then I wanted to ask a question on your wine business. You mentioned it was certainly a tough quarter. Your margins were very low, probably the lowest they've actually been for a number of years. So I guess I was hoping you guys
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then I wanted to ask a question on your wine business. You mentioned it was certainly a tough quarter. Your margins were very low, probably the lowest they've actually been for a number of years. So I guess I was hoping you guys could drill down a little further in some of the things that hurt your business during the quarter. You mentioned your volume was very weak due to the wholesalers reducing year-end inventory. So more color on this. And then any sense what your volume was excluding this inventory fluctuation? And then finally, this begs a question, which I've asked you guys about before, but would love to hear any updated thoughts or plans that you might have for this business over the next several years in terms of further investments and if you need to actually increase your investments, possibly to turn the business around.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks for the question. Listen, I think you have to put the wine quarter in context. If you look at its income growth over the last 5 years, it's grown double-digit. Call it, I don't know, 12%, give or take. And so you have to place the quarter in
componenttext: Okay, thanks for the question. Listen, I think you have to put the wine quarter in context. If you look at its income growth over the last 5 years, it's grown double-digit. Call it, I don't know, 12%, give or take. And so you have to place the quarter in context. They had a tough quarter, there's no denying it. There was inventory that got burned off from the end of the year and the Easter holiday was pushed back into the second quarter this year. So that has the effect on all the numbers if you called out in terms of the volume and, obviously, in terms of the margin. The wine company does a terrific job out there. No quarter is perfect and this is ours, I guess, for the wine business, but they do a great job. I don't see the need for anyone to think that we have to step up in any materially way the investment in the wine company. It was just a tough quarter.

componenttext: I might be a tad more precise in that if you let me. They're sourcing the product to us, as you know. They're licensing it into us for commercialization. We just -- essentially, the inverse of the relationship we have on e-vapor, which is we source the product for them for e-vapor outside the United States, and we license the trademark and the IP to them. The only distinction, of course, is that before the spin-off, there was IP under the Altria tent, which we retained at the spin-off.

componenttext: Right, okay, that's clarifying. componenttext: No, I would agree with you that it's hypothetical, though, I guess. And there's nothing, I guess, that could foreclose the different arrangement being struck than the one that we have today. But what I've described is the arrangement we have today with PMI.

componenttext: Just a quick follow-up on cigarette industry volumes, which improved a bit sequentially versus what we saw in the fourth quarter despite the fact that retail consumption in measured channels appeared to slow. We had some headwinds from slower C store trends, difficult comp. So how did that 3% compared to your expectations? And are there any favorable dynamics at the consumer level, maybe consumer confidence that you point to as having helped support volumes in the short term?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: I guess our view is that it's going back to about where we expected, Matt, is the honest answer. If you look at long-term trends, call it, a 5-year trend for the industry, it's about 3%. As you know, we were flatter there for the period that we've discuss
componenttext: I guess our view is that it's going back to about where we expected, Matt, is the honest answer. If you look at long-term trends, call it, a 5-year trend for the industry, it's about 3%. As you know, we were flatter there for the period that we've discussed previously. Last year was a 2.5%, and now for this quarter we are back at about 3% as our estimate. So our view is that the [ sequential ] decline is what drives this, it has since the 1980s, and it looks to us like it's going about that. In the quarter, there may be some movements in and out because we've got some excise tax activity, particularly in California. But I don't think it's material over the course of the year.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 02, 2017

componenttextpreview: Yes, that's an interesting question. We are talking to state legislatures about the policy issue of which ICOS is but a part of having differential taxing, obviously, on lower risk products, that would make good sense. And tax policy gets changed over tim
componenttext: Yes, that's an interesting question. We are talking to state legislatures about the policy issue of which ICOS is but a part of having differential taxing, obviously, on lower risk products, that would make good sense. And tax policy gets changed over time. So we're working on that, but I don't have anything new to announce on that, but it is one of the elements of our work streams.

componenttext: Okay. Have there been changes in retail or inventory levels in vapor? Have you seen better flexibility in being able to secure and manage shelf space as a result of those rules going into effect?

componenttextpreview: No. I wouldn't say that I distinguish probably how the dynamics with respect to our vapor business, which, as you know, is going quite well with MarkTen XL you saw a big boost in the number of stores that we're in. We see very good consumer response to th
componenttext: No. I wouldn't say that I distinguish probably how the dynamics with respect to our vapor business, which, as you know, is going quite well with MarkTen XL you saw a big boost in the number of stores that we're in. We see very good consumer response to the new product. I would say the thing to watch probably from an industry dynamic are the vape shops. So I know you are familiar with that phenomenon, but they now have to deal with FDA regulation, where they didn't have to deal with any before. So we have seen some evidence that there's been a reduction in the number of vape shops and that the volume is moving to more traditional channels, which would be a good development for our business, of course.
